title: How to write my biography in one line - Quora

response.answer_text: Focus, focus, focus. You won’t be able to fit your whole life’s story in one line and have that line hold any meaning beyond the fact that you were born, you lived, and will someday die. So decide what you NEED to convey in your biography. The needs will vary depending on context. You say in the comment that people often ask what you’re up to. They don’t want a biography in most cases. Again, context matters. Are they a coworker? Then make your line work-related. “It seems like I’m spending all my time answering phone calls. How are things going with you?” A friend? Then make it personal. “I haven’t been sleeping well. I keep having nightmares about my house falling off of a cliff while I’m in it.” Now, if it’s in context to a biography, say, on Quora, you can focus on what you want to be known for. I’m a writer and so I prefer my single line to mention my work and pseudonyms so that people can look me up if they want to. When I write a single-line bio to go with a story that I’ve written for publication, I try to give the reader a sense of who I am as a person and a writer. That usually involves where I’m from and the fact that I have a small farm and weird hobbies, though sometimes I’ll just mention my other work instead so that readers can look up my other writing. If I’m presenting something on gardening at a panel, my bio will consist of my education and experience in gardening. If I’m going to write about physics principles, my bio will focus on my math and physics education and activities. Usually, if you put some time and thought into it, you can get a lot of information into very few words. When you have only one line, it’s often more useful to transmit a small amount of information very well than to try to summarize a bunch of information that doesn’t connect and leaves people feeling confused. On Facebook there’s often something in a window that says ‘what are you up to?’ or whatever. Again, it’s not asking for a biography. Your friends on FB will just want to know what’s on your mind, or what you’ve done that day or the day before, or plans you’re making for the weekend or whatever. It’s very informal. I hope this helps!

Think about key responses about the most important aspects of your accomplishments, goals, and points of notoriety. Practice writing them in five-second sentences. Eventually, as you become more practiced, you'll be able to produce the correct tidbit that isn't too long and is of interest to the person who is asking.
